Fields.DialogueText: Howdy, Cap!
Howdy, Texas!
Ha! Glad you finally learned how to say hello like a genuine Texan.
Well, we have been spending a lot of time together. I suppose I am picking up a few things being around you.
I'm learnin' a thing or two from you too, Cap - like how to sink those banditos. Great job leadin' our fleet against Sabotage and the rest of those doggone Morganas!
It was a tough battle, but having you in the fight made me confident that we'd come out on top.
Thank you kindly, Cap. I've gotta admit though, I was sweatin' a bit when Sabotage had us holed up in that harbor.

Fields.MenuText: Well, don't worry - there's nothing we can't get through together, Texas!
It was nothing your big guns couldn't solve!
Sweating a bit? Why, you were sweating more than a sinner in church!

Fields.DialogueText: You got that right, Cap! We're just like Tonto and the Lone Ranger - hi-yo Bluebonnet, away! Ha!
You really are learnin' how to think like a Texan, aren't ya?
You're gonna make me madder than a wet hen if ya keep talkin' like that, Cap!
In any case, it looks like we've got a few Morgana stragglers still floating in the harbor. Got enough energy left for a quick mop-up operation?
When it comes to fightin', I'm always ready and rarin' to go!
@BATTLE
*PUNCTUATING WHINNY*
*PAW* *SNORT*
It's funny bein' on dry land again. I feel like a…
Like a fish out of water?
… More like a penned-up bull.
You really don't like sitting still, do you?
It's not so much the sittin' still as it is the not havin' nowhere to go. Bluebonnet's damn near wearin' a hole in my deck, pacin' around like that.
Well, the ships need to be resupplied and refit after all we've just been through.
Sí, Capitán, pero no me gusta. Sittin' in the dock's 'bout as excitin' as a mashed potato sandwich.

Fields.MenuText: It'll only be about a week or so. We'll be back out on the water before you know it.
You never know what you might get in this refit. There might be bigger guns in it for you...
Think of it as a nice opportunity to relax and get some good food before we get back to the fight.

Fields.DialogueText: A whole week? Heck, the war'll be over by then!
Huh… you sure do know how to sweet-talk a Belle, don't ya?
You gotta good point there. I wonder if there are any good barbecue places 'round here…
I love being at sea too, but it's nice to relax and not think about the Morganas for a while.
Well, Cap, funny you mention those Morganas... I was thinkin' - we're still a little vulnerable just sittin' here…
And I know fer a fact that HQ ain't got any patrols goin' along the coast…
… so you want to run some coastal defense patrols in local waters while we wait for all the other ships to finish refitting?
Bingo!
Well... I suppose we will have time to relax once the war is over.
It'll be over by Christmas, Cap! I'll get the engines started for ya. Let's see if we can't rustle up some Morganas 'round here!
I do admire your motivation, Texas! I suppose a quick cruise around the neighborhood wouldn't hurt…
@BATTLE
*APOLOGETIC WHICKER*
*SEAGULLS*
Boy, howdy! There were more Morganas out there than you could shake a stick at!
Yes, and it was shocking how close they were to the shore. I've already let HQ know.
We sure did take care of 'em right quick, though.
Well, ever since we enacted your “Shoot first, ask questions later” policy, it has improved our reaction time a bit. It's given us just the advantage we need against the Morganas.
Like I'm always sayin', Cap, we can't overthink these things.
We do need to drill the lookouts a little more on their ship silhouette recognition, though.
It's a war, Cap! So the crew accidentally fired on a few merchant ships - these things happen when you're out on the trail!

Fields.MenuText: We're lucky all those salvos we fired fell short. We could have seriously hurt someone!
Protecting those merchant ships is the main reason we're out here. We've got to do everything in our power to ensure their safety.
It'd be a disaster if we hit a merchant ship!

Fields.DialogueText: I am a little disappointed in the crew's marksmanship, but I see yer point.
Aw, yer right, Cap! Ain't no use accidentally hittin' the ships we're meant to be protectin'.
Aye, Cap. I'll do more trainin' with the crew to make sure that never happens.
Well, I think we're in agreement that we do have to be more careful. Shooting quickly is great, but we need to positively identify targets before we fire on them.
De acuerdo, Capitán.
This harbor is one of the biggest shipping hubs in the region, too. Keeping the shipping lanes clear in and out of here is critical for the war effort.
All the Morgana activity in the area lately has me concerned. It could cause a lot of problems if they start showing up in greater numbers.
Suppose we oughtta keep patrolin' the waters 'round here, then. Least we can do, really.
Yes. I thought we'd get a little down time in port, but let's head out for another patrol.
I'm pretty sure I see some Morganas comin' over the horizon, Cap. Let's go rope 'em up.
You're sure they're Morganas and not more merchant ships?
Bluebonnet's gettin' staticky again. They're Morganas all right.
Let's get the crew ready then...
@BATTLE
*SNORT* *ENGINE REV*
*SEAGULLS*
Cap, some of the crew's been sayin' they've heard the local sailors talkin' in the bars 'round yonder.
I'm glad the crew has been enjoying some shore leave. As far as I know, they've been staying out of trouble too, which is always good. What have the locals been talking about?
The crew's staying out of trouble as far as you know, which ain't the same thing as stayin' out of trouble all together… but that's petty officer business, Cap. Nothin' ya need to worry about.
Well, I suppose if I don't hear about it, it can't be too serious. But what have the local sailors been saying?
Seems like more fishin' boats have been runnin' into Morganas lately. A couple of merchant ships just vanished completely, so most everyone's keen on sailin' with a convoy lately.

Fields.MenuText: Any idea what happened to the missing merchant ships?
I'll let HQ know that we'll need more convoy support in the area.
Who hasn't run into the Morganas these days?

Fields.DialogueText: Not sure, Cap, but you can bet yer bottom dollar that the Morganas were involved somehow.
I'm always happy to ride shotgun, Cap.
Biggest difference is we've got guns and the merchant ships don't, Cap. Any stagecoach that rolls outta here's gonna catch banditos quicker than a duck on a June bug.
I've got a bad feeling about this whole situation. We smashed Sabotage and an entire armada of Morganas in this very harbor, but it hasn't made a difference.
If anything, the Morganas are only getting stronger. At least it's our last day of refitting at the shipyard. We can get back out to sea tomorrow.
We should run another patrol around the harbor while we're waitin' for the refit, Cap. Things seem to be gettin' worse.
That's a good idea. Have you resupplied with everything you need while we're at port, though? You were short on cattle, barbecue ingredients, and silver bullets when we were last under way.
Don't worry about all that, Cap. Everything should be on the dock ready to load on board 'fore we weigh anchor tomorrow mornin'.
Should I even ask what you've planned to bring along this time?
Only the bare necessities when you're on a long cattle drive, Cap.
I've been at sea my entire career, but I can't say I've ever been on a cattle drive, Texas.
I've trained up my fair share of greenhorns in my day, so we'll get ya squared away 'fore too long.
I appreciate that. Now let's do one more patrol around the neighborhood before we get back out to sea tomorrow.
Aye-aye, Cap. Let's go find the brujas all those old fishermen have been hollerin' about!
@BATTLE
Exactly how are you going to take care of a herd of cows and a horse on a battleship at sea, Texas?
You're overthinkin' things again, Cap! Longhorns don't eat too much, and they're not too thirsty. Same with horses. They're used to takin' care of themselves out on the range.
We've got plenty of room for 'em to run around on the deck too, 'specially if we've got the guns elevated.
Trust me, Cap, they'll all come in handy out there.
… if we take these animals onboard, they're your responsibility, Texas. I don't want to hear you asking for any help arranging for food when we're in the middle of the ocean.
And no ordering the crew to do all the dirty work whenever you have to… swab the poop deck. It's your job to clean up after this whole rodeo you're bringing on board.
Aye-aye, Cap. You've got my word.
All right, then.
Yeehaw! We'll put the big pot on the little pot, Cap!
Okay, all y'all muchachos, you heard the Captain! Let's get these critters on board. Vamanos!
Aye-aye, Texas!
*FOOTSTEPS*
I'm almost afraid to ask what's in those other crates.
Mostly stuff for cookin' - ordered a couple of sets of replacement silverware for the officers' wardroom too.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, thank you for replacing that silverware you melted down for bullets on our last sortie. I know that was a desperate situation, and it won't happen again.
Those silver bullets really did work against the Morganas. I'm glad you're resupplying the magazine.
You really couldn't find a better way to get silver for your bullets?

Fields.DialogueText: Well… about that, Cap. This silver ain't exactly destined for the mess hall. I'm meltin' it all down for more bullets to put down those brujas.
De nada, Capitán. I was half expectin' you to be angry with me again!
This government-issue silverware ain't what it used to be on account of the war, but there was plenty of refit budget left over to procure a few crates.
I suppose we need to prepare ourselves the best we can. The Morganas are getting stronger every day.
*ALARM*
Morganas sighted in the harbor, Captain!
Looks like we'll be leavin' a little early, Cap!
We're going to need more than a few silver bullets to win this war…
@BATTLE
'Sides, Bluebonnet keeps 'em all in line. I think the mare's taken a shine to 'im, however that works.
*SHEEPISH SNORT*
How many are there, Texas?
I lost track countin' again, Cap. Seems like every merchant ship, mail ship, and fishin' boat in the harbor is lined up behind us, waitin' to go.
HQ is reporting a sizable Morgana fleet working its way down the coast, and it's heading straight at us. They're sinking anything they come across without warning.
If any ship leaves this harbor without us ridin' shotgun, they're as good as sunk too.
I agree. And if we stay here…
We'll be trapped by another Morgana blockade.
I've already asked HQ to send help in our direction, but we need to get moving and buy more time until help arrives.
This is the Runaway Scrape all over again, Cap.
The Runaway Scrape?
After the Alamo, the Mexican army chased the rebellin' Texans across the state. The Texans were recruitin' more soldiers and draggin' along their families while the Mexicans burned down their towns.

Fields.MenuText: Well, hopefully they didn't all die in the end, like at the Alamo.
That sounds like a pretty dramatic situation!
We won't let the Morganas burn down this town!

Fields.DialogueText: Naw, they ran for a bit, then turned 'round and caught Santa Anna with his pants down at San Jacinto. Took him prisoner and negotiated a full withdrawal of the Mexican army from Texas.
Yep. But the Texans eventually captured Santa Anna at the Battle of San Jacinto, and negotiated a full withdrawal of the Mexican army.
You got that right, Cap! The Texans stood up to the Mexican army and finally captured Santa Anna, forcin' the Mexican army to withdraw from Texas.
I'm glad the Runaway Scrape ended on a bit more of a positive note for the Texans.
Yep. I don't think we'll be able to do much negotiatin' with these Morganas, though. They're better off sunk to the bottom of the ocean, if you ask me.
We still need to buy more time until we get reinforcements. HQ is reporting the Morgana fleet is even bigger than that last armada we encountered.
*GUNFIRE* *WHINNY*
A horse fitted with guns really shouldn't spook so easily.
Naw, he knows what he's doin'. These Morganas are really startin' to get my goat!
@BATTLE
The harbormaster confirmed that all these civilian ships wanna ride outta here with us.
That last battle wasn't too tough, but the Morgana fleet that's approaching will sink any ships that stay here.
I'm used to runnin' convoys, Cap. That's all I did back in the Great War. It's just like a real long cattle drive, with an occasional shootout with the local banditos.
Your experience will help out. I've done convoy operations before, but never with this many ships to protect.
That's one of the reasons why I brought the longhorns on board, Cap.
What do you mean?
Well, I'm gonna teach you how to ride, rope, herd, and shoot, Cap. These are useful skills out here on the frontier. It'll help you with escortin' merchant ships and gunslingin' with the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: There are a lot of unexpected parallels there, Texas. I hope to learn a lot from you.
I don't see how all this cowboy stuff will help me be a better captain.
Ooh! Feel free to hog-tie me with your lasso - for demonstration purposes, of course.

Fields.DialogueText: Glad we see eye to eye on this one, Cap! We'll have you ridin' like a real cowboy 'fore you know it.
It'll make more sense once we get started. Escortin' ships and herdin' cattle ain't too different, 'cept maybe a longhorn's a little brighter than some of the civvie skippers you might run into.
I don't know what kinda weird things you're into, Cap, but we're just friends, and frankly I'd like to keep it that way.
We'll have more time to talk about this later. Right now we need to focus on getting this convoy out of the harbor. It's going to be chaos with so many ships involved.
Let's ride 'round the herd one more time to get things organized. Then we can get these dogies rollin'.
Hmm… convoys are a lot like herding cattle, aren't they?
Aye, Cap. Just be ready for the Morganas at the mouth of the harbor. We're gonna have to come outta the chute with guns blazin' this time!
@BATTLE
We had to punch holes in a few Morganas, but we got this convoy out of the harbor, Cap!
Great shooting as always, Texas!
Well, the Morganas make it pretty easy when they come straight at us like that.
Where are we headed anyway, Cap? There was so much fuss roundin' up this circus of civvie ships that I forgot to even ask where we were goin'.
We need to put as much space as possible between us and that huge Morgana fleet. If you look at this chart over here, I think it makes sense to head in this direction…
This puts us on an intersecting course with our reinforcements, and also puts us in open water with room to maneuver.
That's true, Cap. Just keep in mind that all these ships we're escortin' are gonna make us slower than molasses.

Fields.MenuText: That's true. We're going to have to fight off some of the faster Morgana ships, but all we need to do is buy time until we link up with the reinforcements.
It doesn't matter how fast we are, as long as we keep moving together and hit any Morganas that pop up.
Texas, I hate to break it to you, but you're an older ship. Most of the modern ships in the fleet are a lot faster than you.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't like the idea of runnin' again, but we've got no other choice with this many civilian ships in the convoy.
I like the way you think, Cap. It's safe to run with the herd, but even safer when you're the bull with the biggest horns.
I ain't old, Cap - I'm experienced! I may not be the fastest, but ain't no one sunk me yet!
I know we're all doing our best, but it looks like we've still got a few Morganas behind us.
They're not gonna let us hightail it outta here without a fight!
@BATTLE
*SNORT* *BLOWS SMOKE*
This whole runaway scrape ain't gonna be easy, Cap! We've got Morganas hot on our heels again!
*BOOM*
Let's try a bit of negotiating with those guns of yours, Texas!
@BATTLE
I don't think that's what they mean by “gunboat diplomacy,” but you did take care of those Morganas.
Seems like they withdrew their ambassadors back down to Davy Jones's locker for now.
They're welcome to stay there as long as they like.
By the way, how are those cows you brought on board? Hope they haven't been too scared from the gunfire.
Oh! We managed to build a little corral below decks for the cattle and horse. As long as they're away from the guns when the shootin' starts, they won't get too spooked.
That reminds me - we need to start trainin' ya up on yer cowboyin'. Whatcha wanna start with - ridin', ropin' or shootin'?

Fields.MenuText: Riding would be a good place to start. Do the horses have their sea legs yet?
Roping would be helpful in case any Morganas manage to get on board.
We are at war, so shooting seems like a logical focus.

Fields.DialogueText: Good question about the horses. They've got four legs instead of two… I'm not sure if that means it's faster or slower for 'em to get their sea legs...
I don't know if the Morganas can even leave their ships, but ropin' 'em would come in handy if they ever do.
A six-shooter's a heck of a lot different than orderin' the crew to fire the ship's guns. For starters, you gotta learn how to aim and pull the trigger yerself.
I'm sure they're all helpful skills to have, so you'll have to show me a little bit of everything.
You've got the talent, Cap, so we'll get you ridin' point sure'nuff!
Bluebonnet don't hardly even need to discipline 'em, ain't that right, boy?
*AUTHORITATIVE SNORT*
All these civvie ships are finally gettin' a hang of this convoy thing, Cap.
That's good to hear. I've never seen such a massive convoy, but we've got to keep everyone close to protect them from the Morganas.
Aye. Any news on that Morgana armada that chased us out of port?
Yes, but it's not good news. The Morganas sank the few ships that didn't choose to leave the harbor with us.
Those Morganas are about as welcome as a tornado on a trail drive.
We'll be seeing more of them. The convoy is moving a little faster than we expected, but it's still a matter of time before the Morganas catch up.
Es verdad? Good thing I started melting down all those new silverware sets we picked up in port.

Fields.MenuText: Those silver bullets put down Morganas fast the last time you used them, so you've got my support.
I suppose you did order the silverware through official channels this time. There's no specific regulation on their use...
Purely from a utilitarian standpoint, we could order 100 regular bullets for every one of those silver bullets you make.

Fields.DialogueText: The Lone Ranger used silver bullets on regular banditos, so he'd definitely use silver bullets on brujas. Now that's a great idea for a serial - “The Lone Ranger vs. the Brujas!”
I know you're thinkin' I'm always tryin' to do things my own way, but I did all the paperwork right proper this time to keep you and me outta trouble!
Cap, you been payin' attention to how many regular bullets it takes to make these Morganas go hasta luego? I figure we're makin' a net savin's here!
Anyway, Cap, I was wonderin' if maybe I've been thinkin' a little too small about these things.
What do you mean?
Well, I've been makin' these tiny little silver bullets to put in my itty-bitty six-shooter here. That works just fine for the Lone Ranger, but I'm a battleship, darlin'!
Right…
So I was thinkin', if I go all in on the silver, I might could make one big ol' shell to load up in the main gun!
That would definitely be the biggest silver bullet the world has ever seen.
Things are always bigger in Texas, Cap.
*ALARM*
We'll have to talk more later. We've got Morganas ahead of us.
@BATTLE
“Home, home on the range…”
Howdy, Texas!
“Where the deer and the antelope play…”
Ahem! Texas!
Oh, howdy there, Cap! Sorry, I was just in the middle of a song.
I can see that. You've got a great voice! Apologies for interrupting, but…
No problem, Cap! I've had some writer's block lately, so I'm playin' some of the old classics for inspiration.
Writer's block? What are you writing?
I like to write songs about all the adventures I get into. So I wrote one about Veracruz, another one about the North Sea during the war…
… and now I'm tryin' to write one about our little Alamo incident with the Morganas, blockaded in that harbor until we fought our way out.

Fields.MenuText: That'll be a good one! You can write about how the brave Texas and Captain worked together to change history!
It does make for a good story - there was drama and so much at stake!
Did you ever write a song about how you ran aground for three days in Long Island Sound?

Fields.DialogueText: You can't brag that much in a cowboy song, Cap. It's not one of them fascist marches or nothin'. It's more about the emotions of the moment.
You got that right, Cap. A good song really pulls on yer heart strings.
Ha! That sounds like somethin' my sister New York would write for a bad vaudeville act.
It's always relaxing to hear you strumming on your guitar. It does brighten up the mood around here.
I can't say I'm the strongest voice in the choir, but my singin's good enough for government work.
Speaking of which, I came to find you because we're about to run into another small fleet of Morganas. Care to shift that nice voice of yours back into shouting mode?
Aye-aye, Cap. I'll get the guns ready!
@BATTLE
*HARMONIZING NICKER*
Ha! Well bless your heart, Cap! You sure are tryin'...
I can't say I've ever ridden a horse on the deck of a ship before…
I admit, there are some challenges here that are a bit out of the norm…
The sea is rocking in one direction, the horse is rolling the other, and the cows are definitely NOT in a herd!
You're the drag rider, Cap. You just point the horse straight at them dogies. They'll turn tail and start moseyin' over to the bow yonder.
I'm ridin' swing, so it's my job to keep 'em together, but ya gotta get 'em rollin' first.

Fields.MenuText: I think my horse is seasick… or maybe I'm the one feeling seasick...
How do I point a horse? There's no helm here...
I'm the trail boss of this here cattle drive, so I should be riding point! Only greenhorns ride drag!

Fields.DialogueText: Cap, if the crew finds out their captain is getting seasick, you ain't ever gonna hear the end of it. So make like a cowboy and ride!
You're usin' yer arms too much, Cap. That's only gonna wear you out, along with yer horse. It's all in the hips and the legs. Keep yer head up and eyes on where you wanna go.
Don't get too big for yer britches, now. Yer all bark and no bite until you learn the basics, Cap!
Oh look, I've got the cows moving!
There ya go! You're pickin' things up quick, Cap.
Once everything is in motion, it's like everything is running by itself.
More or less, but ya gotta keep payin' attention. You're gonna get some stubborn cows at the back that you need to poke every once in a while.
And if yer on flank or swing, ya gotta watch out for the ones that got a mind of their own.
I can't decide whether herding cattle is simple or complicated.
Ha! You don't need to be a genius to drive a herd, Cap... but you do have to be a cowpuncher.
*BOOM*
Hoowee! That concludes our lesson for the day, Cap! You run along to the bridge now, and get started with those Morganas. I'll round up these critters and join ya in a New York minute!
@BATTLE
A rollin' sea ain't all that different from a rollin' plain!
Says the battleship on the robot horse.
*SNORT* *SHRUG*
Texas, I came to tell you that the Morgana fleet that's been following our convoy is getting close.
Figured as much, Cap. There was no way we were gonna outrun 'em.
HQ said our reinforcements are just now setting sail. It's ridiculous how slow HQ reacts sometimes! That means we won't meet up with them for another few days.
That's the problem with the admirals at HQ - all they ever do is sit in their offices and talk about how they oughta do more talkin'. You really wanna conn a desk at HQ someday, Cap?
Well, you have to respect their position and experience, Texas. We need good decision-makers to allocate resources, think strategically, and plan operationally. It's not easy being an admiral.
I'm sure the admirals are havin' a whale of time pushin' all their model ships around the map back at HQ, but we're the ones in the middle of the ocean taking gunfire from Morganas, Cap!

Fields.MenuText: Understood. I've already requested reinforcements as soon as possible.
Commanding a whole fleet is so much responsibility! One day when I've worked my way up to an HQ position, I'll make sure things finally run correctly.
Dealing with one Belle is enough for me. Besides, there's no job better than being a ship's captain. I can't imagine managing an entire fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: We need help pronto! Otherwise we'll have another Alamo on our hands, 'cept this time we've got a hundred civvie ships to look out for too!
Ain't that what they all say, Cap? Yer a heck of a captain, so I'd hate to see yer talent wasted behind a desk.
Ha! You're lucky, Cap! I'm one of the more low-maintenance Belles!
Thanks for the honesty, Texas. I'm doing my best to make sure our ship and crew gets through all this.
What's wrong, Texas? Another headache?
Ugh… I'm gettin' that feeling again - the Morganas are catchin' up to us.
Let's fire a few warning shots to encourage them to stay back.
I think we're well past warnin' shots at this point, Cap. Might as well cut to the chase!
@BATTLE
*WHICKERED REMINDER*
Don't flatter yourself, Bluebonnet. A handful o' rivets now an' then ain't what I call high-maintenance.
*LICKS LIPS METALLICALLY*
Now keep yer arm steady, and focus on the front post, Cap.
You wanna squeeze yer whole hand gently, including yer trigger finger. Yer not pullin' the trigger, yer just squeezin' everythin' together like so.
This isn't how cowboys shoot in the serials I've seen. This is a lot more deliberate.
Lemme tell ya, Cap, if ya shoot a revolver from the hip and work the hammer with yer off hand like those Hollywood types, yer not gonna hit the broadside of a barn.
Understood.
Now put the sight right in the middle of that Sun Tang bottle down yonder, and just squeeze the trigger - it's almost like the gun should surprise ya when it goes off.
Okay… just squeeze…
*GUNFIRE*
Well, that certainly was a surprise!
Morganas, straight ahead!
Huh! You did hit that bottle, though!

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for the coaching, Texas! I'm ready for the O.K. Corral!
I was looking forward to drinking another bottle of that Sun Tang soda...
Can I get a few of those silver bullets from you? Just in case...

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Cap! I reckon you'd hold your own in the Big Fight!
Waco knows how to do soda right, Cap!
Make 'em count, Cap! I'm runnin' out of silver 'round here, but I can spare a few for ya.
That was a great shooting lesson. Time to put that training to good use against these Morganas!
My favorite kinda target practice, Cap!
@BATTLE
It's a strange feeling sitting on a horse and herding cattle around on the deck like this.
It's nice, ain't it? You get that ocean breeze and that quiet sense of freedom.
I have to say, I'm pleasantly surprised that having cows and horses on board has worked out so well.
Makin' queso blanco and ice cream with all that fresh cow's milk has really boosted morale 'round the galley, too.
I'm finally getting a hang of riding and herding, thanks to your advice.
Well, you've picked things up faster than a prairie fire with a tailwind, Cap.

Fields.MenuText: I'm ready to learn how to use that lasso.
Think you could teach me how to barbecue too?
Do you know anything about bull riding?

Fields.DialogueText: Yer ridin' is gettin' pretty good. Makes sense to learn ropin' next.
That's a tall order, Cap. Might not even have enough time on this sortie to get through half of what ya need to know.
Bull ridin'? It's a heck of a lot more buckin' than steer ridin', that's for sure!
Oh, and did you ever run that BODAR experiment to see if the cows could detect the Morganas approaching when our electronics go out?
I've been pretty busy with a dozen other things, Cap. But now that you mention it, the herd does look a little restless right now, don't it?
The cows do look a little nervous... and they are shifting around a bit more than usual.
Something done spooked 'em, Cap. Good thing Bluebonnet's around to be spookier.
You might be right.
*ALARM*
I'm definitely right, Cap! Let's get ready for another shootout with those banditos!
@BATTLE
*DUTIFUL GRUNT*
What's all this, Texas?
Cap, the best thing about running a convoy like this is all the tradin' we can do with all the merchant ships and fishin' boats.
That's really resourceful of you.
It's like we've got our own little economy goin' between all the ships. I've been tradin' the fresh milk from the cows for all sorts of other stuff.
I was against bringing those cows on board, but it's paid off in so many ways. What have you got?
Well, the merchant ships are from all over, so we've got some Indian curry here, and this here is like a… a Vietnamese burrito… and this tomato pie is an Italian tortilla…
It all smells delicious!
It's not what I'm used to, but I like to keep an open mind about these things. Most of it tastes pretty good if you put a little hot sauce on it.

Fields.MenuText: Nothing beats home cooking, but the great thing about sailing the world is being able to try a little bit of everything.
What's the point of trying new food if you cover everything in the same hot sauce?
I bet some of this food would be pretty popular back in Texas if you adjusted the flavors a little bit.

Fields.DialogueText: There's lots of fresh pastures out there, Cap.
It's a flavor enhancer, Cap!
I can't imagine eatin' all this exotic food back in Texas. That sounds a little too cosmopolitan for my tastes.
*ALARM*
Looks like the Morganas want in on this picnic.
The Morganas aren't hungry for our tortillas, Cap - they're hungry for our ships!
@BATTLE
It's Sabotage again, Cap. I can feel her. She's leadin' the armada that's chasin' us again.
Again? We definitely sank Sabotage the last time we saw her.
Well, these brujas have a way of comin' back from the dead.
Maybe the silver bullets aren't working.
I need to get to work on that big ol' silver artillery shell. That'll definitely take care of Sabotage for good.
How many cases of silverware will you have to melt down for that?
The rest of 'em, Cap. But I swear it'll be worth it.

Fields.MenuText: These Morganas sure are tenacious. I wonder what's driving them to cause so much destruction.
Well, even if we run out of silver, we've got plenty of regular shells and torpedos to hit them with.
We'll only have one shot with that silver artillery shell, so we need to make sure it lands on target.

Fields.DialogueText: There was already a war goin' on 'fore the Morganas showed up, Cap. I guess they're just tryin' to fit in.
Aye, Cap, but those don't seem to be workin' too well, do they now?
Don't worry about that, Cap. I ain't gonna miss this one, that's fer sure.
In any case, do you have any idea how close Sabotage is?
It's just a feelin', Cap. It ain't that precise, but I can tell she's the jefe behind this war party.
*GUNFIRE*
The Morganas are getting a little too close to our ships again.
Let's make a little more breathin' room for the herd, Cap!
@BATTLE
I'm gettin' a little tired of all this runnin', Cap.
I don't like it either, Texas, but we need to do it to keep these civilian ships safe.
I got ya, but how close are we to linkin' up with those reinforcements?
It's not as soon as I'd like, but we're almost there.
You know, it's a small miracle that we've managed to protect all of the merchant ships so far.
Knock on wood, Cap. Don't bring up things like that. It's bad luck. I can see yer not the superstitious type - kinda odd for a sea captain.
We're living in the modern world, Texas. It's my job to lead rationally and logically. Merely talking about the possibility of an undesirable event won't make it more likely to happen.
Well, yer temptin' fate then. Just remember to never set sail when there's a ring around the moon. That means bad weather is on the way.

Fields.MenuText: We have the most advanced navy in the world, Texas. A little rain won't stop these ships from sailing.
What's the best thing to do to get rid of these brujas then?
What if these Morganas are ghosts instead of witches?

Fields.DialogueText: If yer gonna do that, you need to put an axe in the ground. That'll split the clouds and keep the rain from comin'.
Bury a knife under your doorstep to keep witches away. Come on, that's just common sense, Cap!
Carry some bread in yer pocket in case ya meet a hungry ghost. But these Morganas ain't ghosts, Cap. That's pretty obvious, seein' as they ain't interested in bread at all.
… All of this is very helpful. I'll keep it mind.
Just doin' all I can to protect you and the crew, Cap.
*ALARM*
I knew this was comin'. Ya had to go and start temptin' fate, didn't ya?
The Morganas have been harassing us for days! This has nothing to do with what I said earlier about us being lucky that we haven't lost any of the merchant ships so far.
Doggone it, Cap! Just quit talkin' and get back up to the bridge. I'll get the guns pointed in the right direction!
@BATTLE
Did you get some salt from the mess to throw over yer shoulder? That should counteract all the bad luck you've been buildin' up.
I feel ridiculous admitting this, but yes, I did.
Bueno, Cap.
Okay, so rope throwin' is our last bit of cowboyin' I'm gonna teach ya.

Fields.MenuText: This will come in handy if I'm riding swing and a cow breaks away from the herd.
I can't wait to rope a Morgana!
Is this rope throwing for bulls or bandits?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Yer really pickin' up on things, Cap! Sometimes these longhorns listen a little better once you've got a rope 'round 'em.
I've never seen a Morgana close enough to rope, but honestly, she might have six bullets in her 'fore I do.
Once you learn how to rope, you can rope just 'bout anything, Cap.
All right, so how do I get started?
Run the rope through the hondo, keep the coil on yer left hand and the spoke on your right, then work yer elbow to get it goin', flip yer wrist to get 'er on the other side…
Square yerself up on what ya wanna hit, then flick it overhand or underhand, but make sure ya follow through to get the loop over whatcha need to.
This sounds way more complicated than your riding and shooting instructions.
It's easier just doin' it than explainin' it, Cap.
*SPLASH*
That's incoming fire from the Morganas.
Huh, wonder if anyone's ever tried to rope incoming fire…
Maybe we can leave that experiment for another time.
Yer right, Cap. Shootin' back has worked well enough so far!
@BATTLE
*CLICK*
Texas, the crew told me you were down here.
Just puttin' the finishing touches on my silver artillery shell, Cap. I needed the heat from the boilers to melt down all this silverware.
I've never seen a shell entirely made of silver before. It's... quite beautiful, actually.
Yep. Kind of a shame to smash it to pieces against Sabotage's hull, but that's what it's made for.
I came to tell you we've got another group of Morganas harassing the merchant ships. We'll need to push them back a bit.
We're doing a heck of a lot of fightin', considerin' we're supposed to be runnin' away.

Fields.MenuText: We're not running away. It's a delaying action to buy time until we can link up with reinforcements.
If we stop moving, we'll be crushed by that Morgana armada behind us. All we can do is keep sailing and fight off their faster ships until help arrives.
Once we meet up with our reinforcements, we can let the merchant ships sail on to safety while we turn and finally engage that Morgana armada.

Fields.DialogueText: I hear ya, Cap. Just wanna make sure we don't end up circumnavigatin' the whole dang globe before we put up a fight.
If we keep pickin' off their little ships like this one by one, it'll be Judgment Day 'fore we put a dent in that armada.
I can't wait to bring those Morganas to justice!
We just need to find our San Jacinto, Cap.
San Jacinto?
It was after the Alamo, when Santa Anna was chasin' the Texans across the state. The Texans were runnin' for weeks, and Santa Anna got tired of chasin' 'em.
Santa Anna thought the Texans were gonna keep on runnin', so he took a little nap at San Jacinto and rested his horses.
Next thing he knows, the Texans turned 'round and overran Santa Anna's camp. Battle was over in 18 minutes! They captured Santa Anna and negotiated a complete withdrawal of Mexican soldiers.
Let's hope for a similar victory - although it might not be easy to negotiate with these Morganas.
*ALARM*
Naw, Cap. I think we can pretty much leave the negotiatin' part outta all this. Let's go take care of those Morganas!
@BATTLE
We're just about to meet up with our reinforcements.
Good timin'. Sabotage is real close now. I can feel her.
We'll be all set to counterattack once we have more support on our side. We just need to keep the convoy safe until then.
I can see a few Morganas runnin' alongside us too. They're tryin' to find out who's the weakest in the herd so they can sneak in and nab 'em.
*BOOM*
Now don't be ugly! Guess they heard me talkin', Cap. Time to rope up some more banditos!
@BATTLE
Hey Cap, that looks like our help on the horizon!

Fields.MenuText: Finally! Our reinforcements are here. Let's plan a counterattack right away.
I wonder if their help will be enough for us to overcome that Morgana armada.
I'm glad you identified the targets before firing on them this time.

Fields.DialogueText: Ahora estás hablando mi idioma, amigo! Time to load up that silver shell into one of the guns.
Don't get gun-shy now, Cap! We've got that silver artillery shell ready to punch a Blue Hole right in the middle of Sabotage!
I'm learnin' as I go, Cap!
We've been running long enough. Time to show Sabotage what we've got!
*WHINNY* *LOADING SHELLS*
The reinforcements have joined our formation! We'll need to provide some covering fire as a distraction while the merchant ships and fishing boats clear the area.
Those civvie ships need to get the heck out of Dodge 'fore the lead really starts flyin'!
Let's pin down those Morganas so the civilians can get out of here safely.
Aye-aye, Cap! Vamanos!
@BATTLE
Nice shooting, Texas! All of the merchant ships and fishing boats have sailed out of range of the Morganas.
We've got the Morganas stopped dead in their tracks, too!

Fields.MenuText: They're not expecting a counterattack at this point, so now is our perfect chance to turn the tide!
With these added reinforcements, we finally have a chance against those Morganas. Let's see what we can do!
Sabotage still worries me. We already sunk her once, and she's come back to get us again.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll catch Sabotage flat-footed, Cap! They're expectin' us to keep running, but we'll turn 'round and give 'em a drubbin'!
We've got plenty of guns on our side now, Cap! We'll win this shootout faster than double-struck lightnin'!
If she keeps comin' back, I'm happy to keep sinkin' her, Cap!
I suppose now's the moment to load up that silver artillery shell. We've only got one chance at this.
Aye, Cap. I'll hit her - don't worry about that!
*WAR WHINNY*
Is that silver shell loaded up?
Aye, Cap! I can see Sabotage comin' over the horizon too.
Okay, line up Sabotage and commence firing when ready.
The gun's ready, Cap! Here we go…
*GUNFIRE*
@BATTLE
Sabotage is definitely taking on water, Texas!
Ha! She sure is! She's lookin' nervous all right!
That silver shell of yours did some serious damage.
She's big hat, no cattle, Cap!
*BOOM*
Aw hell, she ain't sunk yet, Cap!

Fields.MenuText: We've got plenty of ammunition left in the magazines, and plenty of fight left in the crew!
I've still got a few silver bullets in my revolver.
Time to rope her in, Texas!

Fields.DialogueText: Got that right, Cap! Let's give 'er hell!
Hit her like a Sun Tang bottle, Cap!
She's too far away to rope, Cap! Just keep shootin'!
We've got the upper hand, but we can't keep this up much longer!
Don't give up on me now, Cap!
We didn't exactly pull off a San Jacinto, Texas.
Well, I think we did surprise 'em when we stood our ground, but yer right, Cap - these Morganas are putting up a heck of a fight.
Our lines are drifting closer together too, so the gunfire will only get more intense from here.
We are gettin' pretty close to those Morganas... I think we should mount up.
What do you mean? Is that another one of your Texas sayings?
It ain't a Texas sayin' - it's plain English, Cap! We should mount up on our horses.

Fields.MenuText: This is a naval battle, Texas. I don't see how a cavalry charge will help.
Are we going to herd the cows at them?
That's a brilliant idea! We'll scare the life out of those Morganas when we ride in on our horses!

Fields.DialogueText: We ain't chargin' 'em, Cap! Don't be silly.
Now what good would that do? Those Morganas would grind our longhorns into hamburgers 'fore we knew it.
Exactly, Cap! Just a way to intimidate 'em a bit.
Sometimes it's not just shootin' that wins a war, Cap. Sometimes just lookin' like yer ready to do some shootin's enough.
When a new sheriff rides into town, he ain't gotta shoot anyone. He just rides in sitting tall in the saddle, lettin' people know what's what. That's gunboat diplomacy, Cap.
*BOOM*
All right, we'll go get the horses after this next salvo.
You're the trail boss of this cattle drive, Cap!
@BATTLE
*APPROVING SNORT* *BRANDISH*
I feel a little silly sitting on this horse… and a bit vulnerable to gunfire too.
Just sit tall in yer saddle - show those Morganas who's boss.
Okay - I'm ready for one last ride.
Ya ain't a Lone Ranger on this one. I'm right here next to ya, Cap.
Thanks, Texas. I can always count on you.
Now don't get all sentimental on me, Cap… let's bring these banditos to justice!
@BATTLE
Well, we sunk Sabotage again, Texas. If she comes back for a third time, she's definitely a witch.
The second time wasn't enough scientific evidence for ya?
You've got a good point there.
In any case, all the civilian ships in the convoy are safe. We've cleared the area of Morganas - and the merchant ships, mail ships, and fishing boats are all going their separate ways.
I suppose this is where we ride off into the sunset, Cap.
I suppose so, but I bet it won't be long until we see those Morganas again.
If they do come back, we'll be here waitin' for 'em.
Let's take the horses fer one last victory lap 'round the deck 'fore we put 'em back in the corral, Cap.
One last victory lap? Yes, let's do that, Tonto... Hi-yo Silver, away!
Hey, that's my line, Cap! Get back here! Who ya callin' Tonto? I taught ya how to ride in the first place!
